messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Distributed Saddle-Point Problems: Lower Bounds, Near-Optimal and Robust Algorithms The research of A. Beznosikov and A. Gasnikov was supported by a grant for research centers in the field of artificial intelligence, provided by the Analytical Center for the Government of the Russian Federation in accordance with the subsidy agreement (agreement identifier 000000D730321P5Q0002) and the agreement with the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology dated November 1, 2021 No. 70-2021-00138.

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper focuses on the distributed optimization of stochastic saddle point problems. The first part of the paper is devoted to lower bounds for the cenralized and decentralized distributed methods for smooth (strongly) convex-(strongly) concave saddle-point problems as well as the near-optimal algorithms by which these bounds are achieved. Next, we present a new federated algorithm for cenralized distributed saddle point problems â€“ Extra Step Local SGD. Theoretical analysis of the new method is carried out for strongly convex-strongly concave and non-convex-non-concave problems. In the experimental part of the paper, we show the effectiveness of our method in practice. In particular, we train GANs in a distributed manner.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Distributionally robust logistic regression",
        "Communication complexity of distributed convex learning and optimization",
        "Solving a class of non-convex min-max games using adaptive momentum methods",
        "Lectures on Modern Convex Optimization: Analysis, Algorithms, and Engineering Applications",
        "Randomized gossip algorithms",
        "A first-order primal-dual algorithm for convex problems with applications to imaging",
        "Reducing noise in gan training with variance reduced extragradient",
        "Training gans with optimism",
        "Local stochastic gradient descent ascent: Convergence analysis and communication efficiency",
        "Efficient methods for structured nonconvex-nonconcave min-max optimization",
        "A general framework for a class of first order primal-dual algorithms for convex optimization in imaging science",
        "Finite-Dimensional Variational Inequalities and Complementarity Problems",
        "The complexity of making the gradient small in stochastic convex optimization",
        "A distributed algorithm for minimum-weight spanning trees",
        "A variational inequality perspective on generative adversarial networks",
        "Nips 2016 tutorial: Generative adversarial networks",
        "Generative adversarial networks",
        "Efficient algorithms for federated saddle point optimization",
        "On the convergence of single-call stochastic extra-gradient methods",
        "Efficiently solving MDPs with stochastic mirror descent",
        "Solving variational inequalities with stochastic mirror-prox algorithm",
        "Advances and open problems in federated learning",
        "Gossip-based computation of aggregate information",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "Federated learning: Strategies for improving communication efficiency",
        "The extragradient method for finding saddle points and other problems",
        "Cifar-10 (canadian institute for advanced research)",
        "Interaction matters: A note on non-asymptotic local convergence of generative adversarial networks",
        "Accelerated linear iterations for distributed averaging",
        "A decentralized parallel algorithm for training generative adversarial nets",
        "A decentralized proximal point-type method for saddle point problems",
        "Towards deep learning models resistant to adversarial attacks",
        "Distributed training strategies for the structured perceptron",
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Optimistic mirror descent in saddle-point problems: Going the extra (gradient) mile",
        "Monotone (nonlinear) operators in Hilbert space",
        "Conditional generative adversarial nets",
        "Ray: A distributed framework for emerging ai applications",
        "A decentralized algorithm for large scale min-max problems",
        "Distributed subgradient methods for multi-agent optimization",
        "Prox-method with rate of convergence o(1/t) for variational inequalities with lipschitz continuous monotone operators and smooth convex-concave saddle point problems",
        "Problem complexity and method efficiency in optimization",
        "Dual extrapolation and its applications to solving variational inequalities and related problems",
        "Introductory lectures on convex optimization: A basic course, volume 87",
        "Lower complexity bounds of first-order methods for convex-concave bilinear saddle-point problems",
        "Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library",
        "Training gans with centripetal acceleration",
        "Unsupervised representation learning with deep convolutional generative adversarial networks",
        "Decentralized distributed optimization for saddle point problems",
        "Optimal algorithms for smooth and strongly convex distributed optimization in networks",
        "Understanding machine learning: From theory to algorithms",
        "Optimal gradient tracking for decentralized optimization",
        "Local sgd converges fast and communicates little",
        "Unified optimal analysis of the (stochastic) gradient method",
        "A modified forward-backward splitting method for maximal monotone mappings",
        "Multi-consensus decentralized accelerated gradient descent",
        "On lower iteration complexity bounds for the saddle point problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Distributed Saddle-Point Problems: Lower Bounds, Near-Optimal and Robust Algorithms The research of A. Beznosikov and A. Gasnikov was supported by a grant for research centers in the field of artificial intelligence, provided by the Analytical Center for the Government of the Russian Federation in accordance with the subsidy agreement (agreement identifier 000000D730321P5Q0002) and the agreement with the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology dated November 1, 2021 No. 70-2021-00138., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
